java.time.format.DateTimeParseException is returned when LocalDateTime.parse()  is called on a Date string lacking a time portion like '23 July 2020' (dont know why convertDateTimeFrom is called instead of  convertFrom for such values). Hence added parseDefaulting for time part when it is missing.
Will check for other such occurrences.
This test calls makeRepayment (which other Tests also call and have no issues) and it returns 500. I also used postman to test the endpoint it called and it returned successfull.
Making repayment on locally running community app also work.
Also tried the endpoint this test calls on postman and it was successful too.
I wonder why these tests are failing. Is it something you added thats causing them to fail?
Just out of interest - why was it needed to explicitly specify ZoneId? Wouldn't just calling now() have worked as before?

It was just a warning from Error Prone that requires one to must  an explicit ZoneId( whether default). And I think it will be easier to replace ZoneId.systemDefault() with the tenant's timezone in another PR.

Instead of changing all of these inputs, should we not consider changing the pattern to be "d M y" instead? My worry would be that there may be many clients not using the leading zero.
But of course changing the pattern is not going to be error-free either as this is also being sent by the client. Can you see any way of retaining backward compatibility?
Can't see anyway now. But will look into this.
Why do we use a mix of LocalDate (no timezone) and ZonedDateTime (with timezone) - what's the logic here?
